newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil Finance Min dismisses soybean tax report.
newsitem.headline: Brazil Finance Min dismisses soybean tax report.

text.p: Brazil's Finance Ministry is not considering imposing any tax on soybean exports contrary to a report today in local business daily Gazeta Mercantil, a senior Finance Ministry spokesman said. "The Finance Ministry categorically dismisses the report today in Gazeta Mercantil. It is not considering any tax on soybean exports," the spokesman said.
The report said the government was studying a number of ways to slow down soybean exports, one of which could be a tax.

Citing a unidentified source in the Finance Ministry, the newspaper said the government was concerned reduced crushings because of anticipated high soybean exports could lead to crushing industries laying off workers.
Yesterday rumors Brazil was considering a tax on soybeans and/or soymeal circulated in the Chicago futures market.
A spokesman for the price monitoring department at the Finance Ministry yesterday denied that the ministry was drawing up any such proposal.
Brazil's government is counting on record revenues from soycomplex exports to improve its 1997 trade balance.

Although traders already expect soybean imports later in the year to make up for exports of up to eight million tonnes, they argue it is better to take advantage now of higher international prices and then buy later when world supply is greater and prices lower.
The sharp rise in soybean exports is due to the removal last year of the ICMS export tax which was 13 percent on soybeans, 11.1 percent on soymeal and eight percent on soyoil.
Previously the tax advantage in exporting soyproducts had limited overseas sales of soybeans.
